stem: Following review of the newborn's EHR, including nurse's notes, vital signs, lab results, and physical exam findings, complete the following sentence regarding appropriate nursing actions.
template: The nurse should {{blank1}} the neonatologist immediately, specifically because {{blank2}} requires immediate intervention.
options: the presence of nasal flaring and grunting

blanks.correctOption: the presence of nasal flaring and grunting

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 08:00: Newborn male, born at 39 weeks via spontaneous vaginal delivery. Apgar scores 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes. Initial assessment within normal limits. 10:00: Noted to have increased work of breathing with nasal flaring and grunting. Color is pink centrally but circumoral cyanosis is present. Oxygen saturation 88% on room air. 10:15: Placed on nasal cannula at 2L/min, oxygen saturation now 92%. Respiratory rate 64 and labored. Heart rate 160. Temperature 37.1°C axillary. Mucus membranes appear moist. Infant is alert but tires quickly with feeding. Mother present at bedside. Pediatrician notified. 10:30: Continuing to monitor respiratory status and oxygen saturation. Preparing for potential transfer to NICU if respiratory distress worsens. Will continue to assess and document findings every 15 minutes.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: General: Term newborn, active, but tires easily. Skin: Pink centrally, circumoral cyanosis noted. Respiratory: Nasal flaring and grunting present. Increased work of breathing. Cardiovascular: Regular heart rate and rhythm, no murmurs auscultated. Neurological: Alert, responds to stimuli. Musculoskeletal: Moves all extremities equally.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content: Monitor vital signs every 15 minutes. Assess respiratory status closely. Administer oxygen as needed to maintain oxygen saturation >90%. Notify neonatologist of any changes in condition. Prepare for potential transfer to NICU.

rationale.correct: The newborn is exhibiting signs of respiratory distress, including nasal flaring, grunting, and circumoral cyanosis. These findings indicate significant respiratory compromise and the need for immediate intervention by a neonatologist. Prompt notification allows for timely evaluation and management to prevent further deterioration.
rationale.incorrect: While other options may be part of routine newborn care or address other potential issues, the priority in this scenario is the newborn's respiratory distress. Addressing the respiratory distress is crucial for stabilizing the newborn's condition.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 1
answerBreakdown.content: The presence of nasal flaring and grunting indicates increased work of breathing as the newborn attempts to maintain adequate oxygenation. Notifying the neonatologist ensures prompt evaluation and management of the respiratory distress. This is the priority action.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 2
answerBreakdown.content: Nasal flaring and grunting are signs of respiratory distress. These signs can quickly lead to hypoxemia and respiratory failure if not addressed promptly. The neonatologist can determine the underlying cause and implement appropriate interventions, such as further respiratory support or treatment of underlying conditions. This requires immediate attention.

clinicalPearls: Nasal flaring and grunting are classic signs of respiratory distress in newborns and indicate increased work of breathing.
Circumoral cyanosis indicates hypoxemia and requires immediate intervention to improve oxygenation.
Early recognition and management of respiratory distress in newborns are crucial to prevent complications such as respiratory failure and long-term sequelae.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting 'initiate phototherapy' due to the slightly elevated bilirubin is a common mistake, but respiratory distress takes immediate priority. Focusing on a less critical issue can delay necessary interventions.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize interventions based on the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation). Address respiratory issues before other concerns. Always assess for signs of respiratory distress first.

mnemonic.title: Nasal Flaring & Grunting
mnemonic.expansion: NFG: Notify Fast, Get going! (Neonatologist, Fast action required!) Remember ABCs: Airway, Breathing, Circulation.
